See how easy it is to set up, bind data, group, sort, page, and more. Fiddle with the live samples or install it and try it for yourself, but donâ€™t missÂ it.

  • Fresh data suggests that Microsoft Edge is on the verge of overtaking Safari as the world's second most popular desktop browser.

Quick refresher: The @layer feature allows us to define explicit contained layers of specificity (so we can avoidÂ hacks).

Animating-In a Newly Added Element â€” Using @keyframes just might remove the need for JavaScript when animating newly added DOMÂ elements.

Stephanie Eckles

X-Team

Hired

Simple.css: A 'Classless' CSS Framework â€” Similar to SPCSS, which we shared previously. This one includes dark mode and some nice typographic features for quickly setting up landing pages or other simpleÂ projects: "By 'classless' I mean that there are no CSS classes anywhere in the CSS orÂ theÂ HTML." SemanticÂ HTMLÂ FTW!

Simple.css

Stylo: An Open Source WYSIWYG Rich Text Editor for JavaScript â€” Based on a web component, no dependencies, and you can configure the default toolbar to suit your appâ€™sÂ needs. Being able to edit the project's homepage is a neat touch.

David Dal Busco

Project Management for Software Teams Has Never Been Easier

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Atropos: Touch-Friendly 3D Parallax Hover Effects â€” The easiest and fastest way to fool the eye into thinking the screen has somehow developed three-dimensional capabilities (and, admittedly, annoy some users - so be careful) is to use parallex effects as demonstrated on theÂ project'sÂ homepage.

Vladimir Kharlampidi

Mailwind: Use Tailwind CSS to Design HTML Emails â€” Just add Tailwindâ€™s utility classes as you normally would, then install and run Mailwind via npm to generate the accompanying CSS or inlinedÂ HTML.

Soheil Rashidi

A Pure CSS Working Stopwatch â€” This is a neat little CSS stopwatch demo that actually works â€” which is possible thanks to the Houdini @property (as such it only works in Chrome and Edge rightÂ now). Give it a try.

Jhey Tompkins codepen

items.title: Backend languages driving the frontend?
items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹529 â€” February 16, 2022 | Read on the web

Hello, CSS Cascade Layers â€” Explores how cascade layers (a new mechanism for scoping cascade logic within discrete 'layers') work, how they will help us write CSS with more confidence in the future, along with use-cases and visualÂ examples.

Ahmad Shadeed

Handling the Version 100 Milestone in Chrome and Firefox â€” Both Chrome and Firefox will reach version 100 in a couple of months. This post looks at the timeline of events so far towards fixing potential user agent string detection issues, the strategies that Chrome and Firefox are taking to mitigate the impact, and how youÂ canÂ help.

Karl Dubost, Chris Peterson, Ali Beyad

Building Progressive Web Apps from Scratch â€” Join Maximiliano Firtman for this detailed video course covering creating and publishing PWAs, looking at components, web app manifest, service workers, distribution, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Move Over JavaScript? How Some Backend Languages are Coming to the Front-End â€” You might think this is about using WebAssembly to run Python in the browser or something, but no. Itâ€™s about the growing popularity of maintaining a WebSocket connection to a backend process and rendering HTML on the fly from the backend, as seen in modern Elixir and Rails stacks. Food forÂ thought!

GitHub

The State of JS 2021 Results â€” The results from the annual â€˜State of JSâ€™ survey are now out, with plenty of interesting, well-presented data points to go through. React remains the top front-end framework ofÂ choice.

Sacha Greif

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • WebGL 2.0 has fully arrived, and application authors can target it withÂ confidence.
  • Netlify is now sponsoring the full-time open source development of popular static site generator Eleventy, as Zach Leat explains here.
  • Opera now allows/accepts emoji-only web addresses. Whether users will, on the other hand, remains to be seen.
  • The Software House is currently seeking responses to its community-driven 'State of Frontend' survey.
  • Chrome OS Flex is a neat, green initative to bring a cloud-based OS to older devices in an effort to prolong their working life.
  • Here's a neat HTML and CSS visualization/diagram showing, as a funnel, just how the cascade works.
  • Ok, it's not frontend related in the immediate sense, but this post on the 'declining' quality of Google search results is interesting and worth a read.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The File System Access API with Origin Private File System â€” WebKit now supports this new API (in the Safari 15.4 beta and Safari Technology Preview), making it possible for web apps to create, open, read, and write files directly, or create directories and enumerate theirÂ contents. Here's an update on how Firefox is handling things too.

Sihui Liu (WebKit)

Getting Started with the File System Access API â€” â€¦and in relation to the above. Hereâ€™s a look at how you might useÂ it.

Charlie Gerard

The Intended Wordle Font That Nobody Can See â€” The author explains how the number one mistake in web typography is not providing the font files. This may have happened with Wordle, too.

Oliver SchÃ¶ndorfer

Perfectly Pointless Web Design Done Well â€” Celebrates the whimsical side of web design. Those weird, wacky, sometimes pointless sites that make the webÂ fun.

Frederick Oâ€™Brien

How to Avoid Production Errors Caused by Content on JamstackÂ Sites

Kontent by Kentico sponsor

Building an Adaptive Favicon â€” A foundational overview of how to build an adaptive favicon which changes depending on your light/dark themeÂ preferences.

Adam Argyle

Today, The Distant Future â€” On the often fast and slow world of webÂ standardsâ€¦

Jeremy Keith

From 'Tumblr Girl' to Engineer: How The Platform Inspired A Generation of Women toÂ Code
Elizabeth de Luna

'Why Safari Does Not Need Any Protection From Chromium'
Niels Leenheer

Adobe XD, Where Did It Go Wrong?
Greg Lewis

Jobs

Fullstack Engineer (Remote, EU Timezones) â€” Weâ€™ve built a product thousands of people love (See Trustpilot if you donâ€™t believe us). We need your help with Node &Â TypeScript.
Feather

Senior Frontend Engineer (React) â€” Remote / NYC â€” We're the leading spend management platform for businesses. Small cross-functional front-end operations using React andÂ TypeScript.
Ramp

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Apache ECharts: An Open Source JS Visualization Library â€” The release notes go into plenty of detail about whatâ€™s in the newest release, including keyframe animations, custom loading animations, and a new SVG renderer with improved performance. Lots of demos here too.

Apache Software Foundation

Free Activity Feeds & Chat APIs for Qualifying Teams â€” Unlock enterprise-grade features, functions, and UI components completely free for your startup or side project with the Maker Account fromÂ Stream.

Stream sponsor

SPCSS: A Minimal, Classless Stylesheet for Simple HTML Pages â€” Definitely best for text-based content and it will automatically render in dark mode according to system preferences. You can try it here.

Susam

Minze: A JavaScript Framework for Native Web Components â€” Based on the latest web component standards and it allows you to build portable component libraries that you can use on anyÂ project.

Sergej Samsonenko

Polka Dot Generator: Generate CSS for Custom Polka Dot Pattern Backgrounds â€” The generated code uses custom properties along with CSS gradients. You can adjust color, size, and blur of theÂ dots.

Brian Louis Ramirez

Griffel: CSS-in-JS with Ahead-of-Time Compilation â€” From Microsoft, another option for a CSS-in-JS solution. This one boasts near-zero runtime, SSR support, and styles defined with JS objects, among otherÂ features.

Microsoft

pppointed: SVG Arrow Maker with All Kinds of Decorative Styles

Seb

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» ...and finally

An Inside Look at a Modern Web Browser â€” We featured this fantastically illustrated four-part series back when it was first published in 2018, but it's recently been doing the rounds again on Twitter. It remains an excellent explainer on how modern browsers work, with a focus on Chromeâ€™s architecture, and how it ultimately renders code into functionalÂ sites.

Mariko Kosaka

items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹528 â€” February 9, 2022 | Read on the web

A-Frame 1.3: A Framework for Building WebVR Experiences â€” A web framework for building virtual reality experiences that work on Vive, Rift, Quest, as well as desktop and mobile platforms, including in the browser (as the demos hereÂ show).

A-Frame VR Team

iOS 15.4 Beta Suggests Apple to Support Push Notifications from Web-Based Apps â€” Looks like Apple is working on bringing web-based notifications to iOS â€”Â which would be a real big win for a range of web-basedÂ apps.

Sami Fathi

Weekly Conversations on the Art & Practice of Software â€” For more than 12 years, The Stack Overflow Podcast has been the destination for developers. Hosts Ben Popper, Cassidy Williams & Ceora Ford chat with incredible guests to explore what it means to work in software, and how code is reshaping ourÂ world.

The Stack Overflow Podcast sponsor

How to Favicon in 2022: Six Files That Fit Most Needs â€” â€œItâ€™s time to rethink [..] favicons for modern browsers and stop the icon generator madnessâ€. The high-level advice is this: Prefer SVG over PNG, trust browsers to downscale, drop obscure formats. A good guide to favicons for the modernÂ web.

Andrey Sitnik

â€œEvergreenâ€ Does Not Mean Immediately Available â€” In an age of auto-updating everything, everywhere, there â€œisnâ€™t a single, specific device, browser, and person we cater to when creating a web experienceâ€. Itâ€™s worth keeping this in mind when thinking about your broader approach to the webÂ platform.

Eric Bailey

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • If you squint a bit, you'll notice that Chrome's icon has had a little refresh.
  • Version 8 of dev-browser Polypane is out now bringing a better Elements inspector, performance improvements, forced colors emulation, a new debug tool and more.
  • The web platform is introducing a canonical way to show a browser picker for <input> elements like "date", "time", "color", "file", and others.
  • Jen Simmons of the WebKit team is seeking specific feedback on any "bugs and missing features" that you've run up against in Safari.
  • Did you know that screen readers may read 'M' or 'm' as 'metre'? So 3m for example may be read as "three metres" and not, say, "three million" as possiblyÂ intended.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Reducing the Webâ€™s Carbon Footprint: Optimizing Social Media Embeds â€” A look at what we can do to reduce the environmental impact of social media embeds and social sharing widgets â€” plus some strategies to avoid them altogether. These double-up as great performance tipsÂ too.

Michelle Barker

Replace JavaScript Dialogs with HTML's <dialog> â€” How to replace JavaScript dialogs with the HTML dialog element with the same functionality as the alert(), confirm(), and prompt() methods.

Mads Stoumann

What Web Frameworks Solve: The Vanilla Alternative â€” Suggests a few patterns of how to use the web platform directly as an alternative to some of the solutions that are offered byÂ frameworks.

Noam Rosenthal

Aspect Ratio is Great â€” aspect-ratio is a great example of a humble property that fills a long-awaited need in the CSS, as demonstratedÂ here.

Michelle Barker

Project Management for Software Teams Has Never Been Easier â€” Shortcut is fast and intuitive project management built for developers. Delight the scrum gods and try itÂ now.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Creating Generative SVG Grids â€” Goes through how to create some rather colorful, generative grid designs with JavaScript andÂ SVG, and then animate them too. The end result is pretty neat.

Alex Trost

CSS Animations: A Complete Guide for Beginners â€” For those just getting started with CSS, this covers all the parts of the CSS animations spec with an interactive demo for each of theÂ features.

Louis Lazaris beginner

A Deep Introduction to WordPress Block Themes â€” This is a high-level look at block themes and full-siteÂ editing.

Ganesh Dahal

Preventing Smooth Scrolling with JavaScript

The CSS from-font Value Explained in Four Demos

GitHub

Josh Collinsworth

  • WordPress version 5.9 is out now â€”Â here's a look at what's new.
  • Rachel Andrew looks at some of the interesting features that have landed in stable and beta web browsers during the last month.
  • A state court in Germany has ruled that using Google Fonts on your site breaches GDPR.
  • Talking of GDPR, a particular variant of those 'consent popups' that many web users will be familar with have been deemed illegal.
  • The latest version of Bootstrap's popular icon library is out now, including over 140 new icons. This brings the collection up to nearly 1,700 icons.
  • Firefox suffered an outage last month, here's a retrospective digging into the technical details of what happened.
